Hi Joel, Jeff, Vassilis...

I just have a couple of questions/comments:

Th=
ere's been talk about NS providing smooth fitness landscapes, but is
there =
evidence that the landscape is actually smoother? Another alternative
might=
 be that there are simply more path ways for evolution to take. Or in
your =
minds are these the same thing? It sounds like you think they are at
least =
related, if not one and the same thing, Joel, when you say *"I do
believe t=
hat gradients of novelty are often smoother than objective fitness
gradient=
s, perhaps because there are more of them". *Not sure how
interesting this =
is, but maybe it's important to distinguish between
methods that produce sm=
oothness versus many path ways.

The paper on NS plateaus sounds interestin=
g, I look forward to seeing it! I
(think) I have seen this occur in my own =
experiments. A lot of recent work
has used multi-objective EAs to combine n=
ovelty and objective search. In
light of NS plateaus I now think this needs=
 be implemented very carefully
(more carefully than I have been doing at an=
y rate ;)), since if the
objective search has too much influence it could p=
revent exploration beyond
one or two mutations, preventing the EA from gett=
ing beyond the NS plateau.
Perhaps others have already figured this out and=
 I'm late to the game: some
work has probabilistically applied the objectiv=
e function (don't have any
cites off the top of my head) to mitigate this).=


Finally, on a side note, last night I came across this article about a lo=
ng
period of stagnance (between 1.7 billions and 750 million years ago) in
=
natural evolution:
http://www.newscientist.com/article/mg22229672.900-why-d=
id-evolution-stall-during-the-boring-billion.html#.U2Vv4HWSz0I.
The article=
 talks about how the (physical) environment during this
period
was very sta=
gnant, but then plate tectonics kicked off, perturbing
evolution to produce=
 new (more complex) species. Joel's comment about
NS, *"there's
no equilibr=
ium in the system because in order to stick around in the
population, you m=
ust always be doing something different than you were in
the past"*, made m=
e think about it, and about how NS is perhaps the
ultimate perturbation mec=
hanism.

Cheers,
Oliver


T: 0421 972 953 | E: oliver.coleman@... | W=
: http://ojcoleman.com

om> wrote:

>
>
> All,
>
>
>
> There seems to be some similarities between =
Novelty Search and Adaptive
> Stochastic Resonance -
> http://citeseerx.ist=
.psu.edu/viewdoc/summary?doi=3D10.1.1.31.4076
>
>
>
> The objective for bot=
h is to extract and amplify =E2=80=9Cboundary=E2=80=9D information
> from t=
he distribution, as opposed to =E2=80=9Ctarget=E2=80=9D information.
>
>
>
=
> Ken Lloyd
>
>
>

=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D*
>
> *Kenneth A. Lloyd, Jr.*
>

ystems Science

> *From:* neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@y=
ahoogroups.com] *On Behalf Of *Jeff
> Clune
> *Sent:* Saturday, May 03, 201=
4 7:38 AM
> *To:* neat users group group
> *Subject:* Re: [neat] Self-adapt=
ive Mutation Rates, Novelty Search and
> CMA-ES
>
>
>
>
>
> Hello Joel and =
Vassilis,
>
>
>
> I=E2=80=99ll respond in this thread since it is focused o=
n the issue of
> self-adatptive mutation rates and novelty search. I=E2=80=
=99ll first respond
> to Vassilis then Joel=E2=80=99s original comments. Pl=
ease see below.
>
>
>
> Self-adaptive mutation rates are a terrible idea:
>=

> Jeff, thanks for pointing this out. That is an interesting paper! To be
=
> honest I haven't read it before; so, you are saying that self-adaptive
> =
mutation rates can be more effective on smoother fitness landscapes,
> corr=
ect?
>
>
>
> Novelty Search:
>
> Joel, could novelty search be seen as a wa=
y of creating a smoother fitness
> landscape? If yes, then based on what yo=
u said, is this the reason why
> self-adaptive mutation rates work better w=
hen coupled with novelty search?
>
>
>
>
>
> I agree with you. Self-adaptiv=
e mutation rates work fine on smooth
> landscapes. Of course, landscapes on=
 any interesting, non-trivial problem
> are rugged, so that means that gene=
rally self-adaptive mutation rates are a
> very bad idea. Novelty search, h=
owever, makes the conversation more
> complex. I agree with you that NS smo=
othes out landscapes, making
> self-adaptive mutation rates far less pathol=
ogical. That said, I=E2=80=99m not yet
> sure that self-adaptive mutation r=
ates are actually a good idea with
> Novelty Search (see below).
>
>
>
>
>
=
> I believe the idea of self-adaptive mutation rates formed the basis for
>=
 more advanced evolution strategies such as CMA-ES. I am not trying to
> de=
fend CMA-ES here, which I agree with Jeff that it works differently than
> =
the basic approach of encoding the mutation rates in the genotype. However,=

> I am wondering whether a combination of novelty search with CMA-ES would=
 be
> a good approach in speeding up the search for novel behaviours.
>
>
>=

> Of course, I can see some disadvantages of CMA-ES, an example being that=

> the genotype is a vector of real numbers with a fixed size... What do yo=
u
> think?
>
>
>
>
>
> I don=E2=80=99t think what makes CMA-ES effective ha=
s anything to do with
> self-adaptive mutation rates. I think that it=E2=80=
=99s advantage is in learning
> correlations. But, as far as I know, it=E2=
=80=99s still forced to mutate genomes
> according to those correlations. I=
 must admit I don=E2=80=99t know the CMA_ES
> literature at all, but my gue=
ss is that if you tried CMA-ES with and
> without a mutation rate on the ge=
nome, you=E2=80=99d get the same result I report
> in my paper: as long as =
the landscape is rugged (i.e. the problem is
> non-trivial), evolution will=
 floor mutation rates and the result will
> underperform the best, fixed mu=
tation rate. Anyone know the literature
> enough to know if I=E2=80=99m rig=
ht? Or anyone care to give it a try?
>
>
>
> Regarding Joel=E2=80=99s claim=
 that whether self-adaptation is a good idea depends
> on whether fitness i=
s based on an objective or NS:
>
>
>
> I love Joel and Ken=E2=80=99s paper =
looking into whether self-adaptative mutation
> rates (SAMR) are a better i=
dea with NS. As I said above, it makes sense
> that SAMR would be less bad =
with NS, because NS smooths out landscapes and
> eliminates peaks, but is i=
t actually a *good* idea instead of just being
> less bad? On that question=
 I am still agnostic pending further research.
>
>
>
> One reason is becaus=
e of "novelty plateaus=E2=80=9D, a concept my students and I
> introduce in=
 our last, not-yet-announced GECCO paper. Novelty plateaus
> exist when, du=
ring novelty search, mutating the current population does not
> immediately=
 produce new behaviors. For example, once the low-hanging fruit
> is consum=
ed, it might take 5 specific mutations to produce a new behavior
> (assume =
that all intermediate mutations have no effect on behavior). In
> that case=
, NS cannot reward those stepping stones to the new behavior, and
> thus th=
ere is no incentive to have a high mutation rate. Since most
> mutations br=
eak things (producing the very un-novel behavior of doing
> little or nothi=
ng), I hypothesize that having a high mutation rate will be
> selected agai=
nst when on such a novelty plateau. In other words, think of
> the long, fl=
at lines of fitness you (Joel) mentioned: We hypothesize that
> those long-=
flat lines also exist in terms of generating new behaviors and,
> if we're =
right, I think there would be a pressure to lower mutation rates
> during s=
uch periods, even though keeping the mutation rate high is exactly
> what y=
ou need to cross the plateau. Of course, a lot of this is
> speculation, an=
d I think a paper on this subject would be very interesting
> and worthwhil=
e for the community.
>
>
>
> Now let me argue against myself, since I=E2=80=
=99m thinking through these issues
> by writing about them in this thread! =
While I can imagine that novelty
> plateaus exist, for the specific purpose=
s of this conversation on mutation
> rates, I can=E2=80=99t figure out if t=
hey would actually cause selection for lower
> mutation rates, because even=
 if you are not generating not-yet-seen-before
> behaviors, you can be gene=
rating non-new behaviors in different regions of
> density in the archive=
=E2=80=A6meaning that you may truly always be on the side of
> a hill and n=
ot on a neutral plateau. What do y=E2=80=99all think?
>
>
>
> An additional=
 reason I=E2=80=99m not yet ready to commit to the claim that SAMR is
> a g=
ood idea with NS is because your paper didn=E2=80=99t show that SAMR did
> =
optimize mutation rates for long-term adaptation. You did not sweep over
> =
the range of fixed mutation rates and show that SAMR found those optimal
> =
rates, or outperformed them. Instead, you showed that it performed better
>=
 than the parameters you had for the initial experiment.
>
>
>
> An final r=
eason I=E2=80=99m agnostic (so far) on the issue of whether SAMR helps
> wi=
th NS is because the evidence in your paper, while very interesting, was
> =
also not overly strong or consistent. I hope you won=E2=80=99t be offended =
and
> think I=E2=80=99m critical of you and Ken or the work. You may be rig=
ht that
> SAMR+NS works, and it would be fascinating if you are, but I woul=
d just
> like to see larger effect sizes, lower p-values, and more consiste=
ncy
> across domains before taking the claim =E2=80=9CSAMR works with NS=E2=
=80=9D to the bank.
> Please see below for some of my specific reasons for =
this claim.
>
>
>
> 1. I don=E2=80=99t see self-adaptive mutation rates hel=
ping a lot in your results:
> in some cases SAMR improved evolvability sign=
ificantly, but not in all, and
> in the cases where the difference is signi=
ficant, the effect size is very
> small and the variance and associated p-v=
alue are high. The same is true
> for performance, where self-adaptation on=
ly helped in one domain, not all,
> and the difference was a jump from ~5% =
to ~10% (a doubling, which is rather
> impressive, but with a p-value of on=
ly < 0.05). I hope I didn=E2=80=99t get any of
> these details wrong. I apo=
logize if I did.
>
>
>
> Personally I=E2=80=99d prefer more tests before I =
really commit to this conclusion
> and start drawing inferences from it. To=
 repeat, I hope you don=E2=80=99t mind that
> I point out that I=E2=80=99d =
prefer more experiments and on more problems before
> fully committing to t=
he view that self-adaptation helps with novelty
> search. As I said, I do t=
hink the result is probably right, as
> self-adaptation works well on smoot=
h fitness landscapes, and NS does
> eliminate peaks and smooth landscapes. =
Moreover, I think it was an
> extremely clever and interesting question to =
ask and issue to raise: I=E2=80=99m a
> big fan of the paper, but I=E2=80=
=99d still love to see follow-up studies on it
> because the result is fasc=
inating, but so far the evidence is not as strong
> as it could be.
>
>
>
>=
 2. You show that Eibd* (=E2=80=9Cevolvability as defined as producing imme=
diate
> behavioral diversity=E2=80=9D) is better for NS with self-adaptatio=
n, but
>
>             a. The real proof is if these organisms actually evo=
lve
> better in a new environment. It would be great to see those data. You=
 have
> provided some evidence for improved long-term evolvability since
> =
performance was higher, but again that was only in one of the domains, and
=
> the difference was not huge.
>
>             b. Did you look at what happ=
ened to the mutation rates? They
> may have still gone down, which could pr=
oduce more Eibd, but at the cost of
> Elt* (Evolvability over the Long Term=
).
>
>
>
> 3. You report that "Initial experiments revealed that evolving a=
 single
> mutation power and rate for each entire genome is too coarse.=E2=
=80=9D That
> suggests that the effect may not be that robust, and may be h=
ard to take
> advantage of in practice. I also noted that in the treatment =
that
> ultimately worked, you took an intermediate route of different mutat=
ion
> rates for different connections, but not one set of mutation rates
> =
per-connection. Out of curiosity, did you also try that and find it didn=E2=
=80=99t
> work?
>
>
>
> Overall, I do think that how bad self-adaptive muta=
tion rates are depends
> on the ruggedness of landscapes, and NS makes them=
 less bad because it
> smooths landscapes. However, I consider the question=
 of whether SAMR are
> beneficial with NS to be a fascinating, open questio=
n that you have
> provided some evidence for, but that we=E2=80=99d all ben=
efit from seeing a lot
> more research into.
>
>
>
> Best,
>
> Jeff
>
>
>
>=

<div dir=3D"ltr">Hi Joel, Jeff, Vassilis...<div><br></div><div>I just have =
a couple of questions/comments:</div><div><br></div><div>There's been t=
alk about NS providing smooth fitness landscapes, but is there evidence tha=
t the landscape is actually smoother? Another alternative might be that the=
re are simply more path ways for evolution to take. Or in your minds are th=
ese the same thing? It sounds like you think they are at least related, if =
not one and the same thing, Joel, when you say <i>"I do believe that g=
radients of novelty are often smoother than objective fitness gradients, pe=
rhaps because there are more of them". </i>Not sure how interesting th=
is is, but maybe it's important to distinguish between methods that pro=
duce smoothness versus many path ways.</div>

<div><br></div><div>The paper=
 on NS plateaus sounds interesting, I look forward to seeing it! I (think) =
I have seen this occur in my own experiments. A lot of recent work has used=
 multi-objective EAs to combine novelty and objective search. In light of N=
S plateaus I now think this needs be implemented very carefully (more caref=
ully than I have been doing at any rate ;)), since if the objective search =
has too much influence it could prevent exploration beyond one or two mutat=
ions, preventing the EA from getting beyond the NS plateau. Perhaps others =
have already figured this out and I'm late to the game: some work has p=
robabilistically applied the objective function (don't have any cites o=
ff the top of my head) to mitigate this).</div>
<div><br></div><div>Finally=
, on a side note, last night I came across this article about a long period=
 of stagnance (between 1.7 billions and 750 million years ago) in natural e=
volution: <a href=3D"http://www.newscientist.com/article/mg22229672.900-why=
-did-evolution-stall-during-the-boring-billion.html#.U2Vv4HWSz0I">http://ww=
w.newscientist.com/article/mg22229672.900-why-did-evolution-stall-during-th=
e-boring-billion.html#.U2Vv4HWSz0I</a> . The article talks about how the (p=
hysical) environment during this period was very stagnant, but then plate t=
ectonics kicked off, perturbing evolution to produce new (more complex) spe=
cies. Joel's comment about NS, <i>"there's no equilibrium in t=
he system because in order to stick around in the population, you must alwa=
ys be doing something different than you were in the past"</i>, made m=
e think about it, and about how NS is perhaps the ultimate perturbation mec=
hanism.</div>
<div><br></div><div>Cheers,</div><div>Oliver</div>

, 2014 7:38 AM<br><b>To:</b> neat users group group<br><b>Subject:</b> Re: =

<u></u>=C2=A0<u></u></p><p =
class=3D"MsoNormal">=C2=A0 <u></u><u></u></p><div><div><div><div class=3D"h=
5"><div><p><span>Hello Joel and Vassilis,</span><u></u><u></u></p><div><p c=
lass=3D"MsoNormal"><span><u></u>=C2=A0<u></u></span></p></div><div>
<p clas=
s=3D"MsoNormal"><span>I=E2=80=99ll respond in this thread since it is focus=
ed on the issue of self-adatptive mutation rates and novelty search. I=E2=
=80=99ll first respond to=C2=A0Vassilis then Joel=E2=80=99s original commen=
ts. Please see below.=C2=A0<u></u><u></u></span></p>
<div><div><div><div><d=
iv><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><p class=3D"MsoNo=
rmal"><span style=3D"font-size:10.5pt;font-family:"Times","s=
erif"">=C2=A0<u></u><u></u></span></p></div></div></div>
</div></div><=
/div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div><bloc=
kquote><div><div><div><div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"background:=
white"><span>Self-adaptive mutation rates are a terrible idea:<u></u><u></u=
></span></p>
</div><div><div><div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"back=
ground:white"><span>Jeff, thanks for pointing this out. That is an interest=
ing paper! To be honest I haven't read it before; so, you are saying th=
at self-adaptive mutation rates can be more effective on smoother fitness l=
andscapes, correct?<u></u><u></u></span></p>
</div><div><p class=3D"MsoNorm=
al" style=3D"background:white"><span><u></u>=C2=A0<u></u></span></p></div><=
div><p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"background:white"><span>Novelty Search:=
<u></u><u></u></span></p></div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"backgro=
und:white">
<span>Joel, could novelty search be seen as a way of creating a=
 smoother fitness landscape? If yes, then based on what you said, is this t=
he reason why self-adaptive mutation rates work better when coupled with no=
velty search?<u></u><u></u></span></p>
</div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal" st=
yle=3D"background:white"><span><u></u>=C2=A0<u></u></span></p></div></div><=
/div></div></div></div></div></div></blockquote><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"=
><span><u></u>=C2=A0<u></u></span></p></div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal">
<s=
pan>I agree with you. Self-adaptive mutation rates work fine on smooth land=
scapes. Of course, landscapes on any interesting, non-trivial problem are r=
ugged, so that means that generally self-adaptive mutation rates are a very=
 bad idea. Novelty search, however, makes the conversation more complex. I =
agree with you that NS smoothes out landscapes, making self-adaptive mutati=
on rates far less pathological. That said, I=E2=80=99m not yet sure that se=
lf-adaptive mutation rates are actually a good idea with Novelty Search (se=
e below).=C2=A0<u></u><u></u></span></p>
</div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span=
><br><br><u></u><u></u></span></p><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><div><=
div><p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"background:white"><span><u></u>=C2=A0<u=
></u></span></p></div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"background:white=
">
<span>I believe the idea of self-adaptive mutation rates formed the basi=
s for more advanced evolution strategies such as CMA-ES. I am not trying to=
 defend CMA-ES here, which I agree with Jeff that it works differently than=
 the basic approach of encoding the mutation rates in the genotype. However=
, I am wondering whether a combination of novelty search with CMA-ES would =
be a good approach in speeding up the search for novel behaviours.<u></u><u=
></u></span></p>
</div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"background:whit=
e"><span><u></u>=C2=A0<u></u></span></p></div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal" s=
tyle=3D"background:white"><span>Of course, I can see some disadvantages of =
CMA-ES, an example being that the genotype is a vector of real numbers with=
 a fixed size... What do you think?<u></u><u></u></span></p>
</div></div><d=
iv><p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"background:white"><span><u></u>=C2=A0<u>=
</u></span></p></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div><p clas=
s=3D"MsoNormal"><span><u></u>=C2=A0<u></u></span></p></div><div><p class=3D=
"MsoNormal">
<span>I don=E2=80=99t think what makes CMA-ES effective has an=
ything to do with self-adaptive mutation rates. I think that it=E2=80=99s a=
dvantage is in learning correlations. But, as far as I know, it=E2=80=99s s=
till forced to mutate genomes according to those correlations. I must admit=
 I don=E2=80=99t know the CMA_ES literature at all, but my guess is that if=
 you tried CMA-ES with and without a mutation rate on the genome, you=E2=80=
=99d get the same result I report in my paper: as long as the landscape is =
rugged (i.e. the problem is non-trivial), evolution will floor mutation rat=
es and the result will underperform the best, fixed mutation rate. Anyone k=
now the literature enough to know if I=E2=80=99m right? Or anyone care to g=
ive it a try?<u></u><u></u></span></p>
</div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><s=
pan><u></u>=C2=A0<u></u></span></p></div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span>=
Regarding Joel=E2=80=99s claim that whether self-adaptation is a good idea =
depends on whether fitness is based on an objective or NS:<u></u><u></u></s=
pan></p>
</div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span><u></u>=C2=A0<u></u></span=
></p></div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span>I love Joel and Ken=E2=80=99s =
paper looking into whether self-adaptative mutation rates (SAMR) are a bett=
er idea with NS. As I said above, it makes sense that SAMR would be less ba=
d with NS, because NS smooths out landscapes and eliminates peaks, but is i=
t actually a *good* idea instead of just being less bad? On that question I=
 am still agnostic pending further research.=C2=A0<u></u><u></u></span></p>=

</div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span><u></u>=C2=A0<u></u></span></p></d=
iv><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span>One reason is because of "novelty=
 plateaus=E2=80=9D, a concept my students and I introduce in our last, not-=
yet-announced GECCO paper. Novelty plateaus exist when, during novelty sear=
ch, mutating the current population does not immediately produce new behavi=
ors. For example, once the low-hanging fruit is consumed, it might take 5 s=
pecific mutations to produce a new behavior (assume that all intermediate m=
utations have no effect on behavior). In that case, NS cannot reward those =
stepping stones to the new behavior, and thus there is no incentive to have=
 a high mutation rate. Since most mutations break things (producing the ver=
y un-novel behavior of doing little or nothing), I hypothesize that having =
a high mutation rate will be selected against when on such a novelty platea=
u. In other words, think of the long, flat lines of fitness you (Joel) ment=
ioned: We hypothesize that those long-flat lines also exist in terms of gen=
erating new behaviors and, if we're right, I think there would be a pre=
ssure to lower mutation rates during such periods, even though keeping the =
mutation rate high is exactly what you need to cross the plateau. Of course=
, a lot of this is speculation, and I think a paper on this subject would b=
e very interesting and worthwhile for the community.<u></u><u></u></span></=
p>
</div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span><u></u>=C2=A0<u></u></span></p><=
/div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span>Now let me argue against myself, sin=
ce I=E2=80=99m thinking through these issues by writing about them in this =
thread! While I can imagine that novelty plateaus exist, for the specific p=
urposes of this conversation on mutation rates, I can=E2=80=99t figure out =
if they would actually cause selection for lower mutation rates, because ev=
en if you are not generating not-yet-seen-before behaviors, you can be gene=
rating non-new behaviors in different regions of density in the archive=E2=
=80=A6meaning that you may truly always be on the side of a hill and not on=
 a neutral plateau. What do y=E2=80=99all think?<u></u><u></u></span></p>
<=
/div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span><u></u>=C2=A0<u></u></span></p></div=
><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span>An additional reason I=E2=80=99m not yet=
 ready to commit to the claim that SAMR is a good idea with NS is because y=
our paper didn=E2=80=99t show that SAMR did optimize mutation rates for lon=
g-term adaptation. You did not sweep over the range of fixed mutation rates=
 and show that SAMR found those optimal rates, or outperformed them. Instea=
d, you showed that it performed better than the parameters you had for the =
initial experiment.=C2=A0<u></u><u></u></span></p>
</div><div><p class=3D"M=
soNormal"><span><u></u>=C2=A0<u></u></span></p></div><div><p class=3D"MsoNo=
rmal"><span>An final reason I=E2=80=99m agnostic (so far) on the issue of w=
hether SAMR helps with NS is because the evidence in your paper, while very=
 interesting, was also not overly strong or consistent. I hope you won=E2=
=80=99t be offended and think I=E2=80=99m critical of you and Ken or the wo=
rk. You may be right that SAMR+NS works, and it would be fascinating if you=
 are, but I would just like to see larger effect sizes, lower p-values, and=
 more consistency across domains before taking the claim =E2=80=9CSAMR work=
s with NS=E2=80=9D to the bank. Please see below for some of my specific re=
asons for this claim.=C2=A0<u></u><u></u></span></p>
</div><div><p class=3D=
"MsoNormal"><span><u></u>=C2=A0<u></u></span></p></div><div><p class=3D"Mso=
Normal"><span>1. I don=E2=80=99t see self-adaptive mutation rates helping a=
 lot in your results: in some cases SAMR improved evolvability significantl=
y, but not in all, and in the cases where the difference is significant, th=
e effect size is very small and the variance and associated p-value are hig=
h. The same is true for performance, where self-adaptation only helped in o=
ne domain, not all, and the difference was a jump from ~5% to ~10% (a doubl=
ing, which is rather impressive, but with a p-value of only < 0.05). I h=
ope I didn=E2=80=99t get any of these details wrong. I apologize if I did. =
=C2=A0<u></u><u></u></span></p>
<div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span><u></u>=
=C2=A0<u></u></span></p></div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span>Personally =
I=E2=80=99d prefer more tests before I really commit to this conclusion and=
 start drawing inferences from it. To repeat, I hope you don=E2=80=99t mind=
 that I point out that I=E2=80=99d prefer more experiments and on more prob=
lems before fully committing to the view that self-adaptation helps with no=
velty search. As I said, I do think the result is probably right, as self-a=
daptation works well on smooth fitness landscapes, and NS does eliminate pe=
aks and smooth landscapes. Moreover, I think it was an extremely clever and=
 interesting question to ask and issue to raise: I=E2=80=99m a big fan of t=
he paper, but I=E2=80=99d still love to see follow-up studies on it because=
 the result is fascinating, but so far the evidence is not as strong as it =
could be.=C2=A0<u></u><u></u></span></p>
</div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal">=
<span><u></u>=C2=A0<u></u></span></p><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span>2. Y=
ou show that Eibd* (=E2=80=9Cevolvability as defined as producing immediate=
 behavioral diversity=E2=80=9D) is better for NS with self-adaptation, but<=
u></u><u></u></span></p>
</div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span><span>=C2=
=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0 </span></sp=
an><span>a. The real proof is if these organisms actually evolve better in =
a new environment. It would be great to see those data. You have provided s=
ome evidence for improved long-term evolvability since performance was high=
er, but again that was only in one of the domains, and the difference was n=
ot huge.=C2=A0<u></u><u></u></span></p>
</div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><=
span><span>=C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=
=A0 </span></span><span>b. Did you look at what happened to the mutation ra=
tes? They may have still gone down, which could produce more Eibd, but at t=
he cost of Elt* (Evolvability over the Long Term).=C2=A0<u></u><u></u></spa=
n></p>
</div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span><u></u>=C2=A0<u></u></span><=
/p></div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span>3. You report that "Initial=
 experiments revealed that evolving a single mutation power and rate for ea=
ch entire genome is too coarse.=E2=80=9D That suggests that the effect may =
not be that robust, and may be hard to take advantage of in practice. I als=
o noted that in the treatment that ultimately worked, you took an intermedi=
ate route of different mutation rates for different connections, but not on=
e set of mutation rates per-connection. Out of curiosity, did you also try =
that and find it didn=E2=80=99t work?=C2=A0<u></u><u></u></span></p>
</div>=
<div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span><u></u>=C2=A0<u></u></span></p></div></di=
v></div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span>Overall, I do think that how bad =
self-adaptive mutation rates are depends on the ruggedness of landscapes, a=
nd NS makes them less bad because it smooths landscapes. However, I conside=
r the question of whether SAMR are beneficial with NS to be a fascinating, =
open question that you have provided some evidence for, but that we=E2=80=
=99d all benefit from seeing a lot more research into.=C2=A0<u></u><u></u><=
/span></p>
</div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span><u></u>=C2=A0<u></u></sp=
an></p></div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span>Best,<u></u><u></u></span></=
p></div><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span>Jeff<u></u><u></u></span></p></di=
v><div><p class=3D"MsoNormal">
<span><u></u>=C2=A0<u></u></span></p></div><=
div><p class=3D"MsoNormal"><span>*I=E2=80=99m making these up as I go along=
!<u></u><u></u></span></p></div></div></div></div><div><p class=3D"MsoNorma=
l"><span style=3D"color:white"><u></u><u></u></span></p>
</div></div></div>=
